text: Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: but before I get to that let me just tell you what standard of care will be. One might be the vaccine trial which is basically getting your own blood cells to wake up and try to kill the cancer yourself because right now it’s kind of sleeping on the job Mr. S____. You have cancer and your immune cells are like ho-hum, nothing’s happening. It’s still letting the cancer do what it wants so that’s an FDA approved treatment. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: No cure but we have some long-term survival benefits so that’s one option. The other option is a different type of chemo so a cousin of the chemo that you had earlier this year. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: The third one is a pill um and it’s a like a super hormone pill that complements what’s going on with your Lupron injections that oh, you love so much. Those are standard of care like we have no studies going on at Karmanos. I could pick one off the shelf and we’d be good to go Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and you know, depending on what your scans show, I actually would favor Provenge, which is the vaccine therapy, because it’s almost like a flu shot. We don’t really know what happens to the PSA but we do know that if you get it in people who get it Patient: Is that a shot or is that through? Doctor: So, here’s where it gets a little complicated. You know, the flu shot is also like a vaccine. That, you know, you just get here. But, in cancer it’s a little bit more complicated. So, what we would do is actually send you to the Red Cross right across the street. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They hook you up to a machine and then they take out your cells so they’re not using my cells or anybody else’s cells. They’re taking out your cells, your immune cells so that when they take it they ship it to Atlanta so if you’ve never been to Atlanta, your cells will be. They wake it up and then they ship it back to me, the like better version of you and then I reinfuse it back to you so that your cells know to find the cancer. That’s the thought of how that medicine works. So, we do that, let’s say the Red Cross on a Monday, I get your stuff back like on a Thursday and then I reinfuse it to you on a Thursday. We do that 3 times and then the treatment is done. It’s self-limited. Okay. Patient: So, that’s your immune system.

text: Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then you’ll come back and see me a week after the first injection, I mean a month after the first injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: At that time you could let us know if you want the twelve month implant or if you want to go with the three month shot. And then we do this for about two years or so and then we stop hormone therapy. By that time you’re done with radiation therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we wait and see what happens. Hopefully the PSA stays low. Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?

DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?

DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly. Doctor: So if you’re seeing some improvement it will just continue to get better. Patient: Yeah I was tell G___ you know it when I’m not as active there’s no problem but uh I started work last night so I can definitely feel… Doctor: That’s very common. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: You’re on the right track. Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: But they didn’t explain to me what that meant. So what do you mean, stabilized? Does that mean that it’s not growing? Does it mean that it’s not, uh, progressing? Does it mean it’s not going the other way? What, what do you mean, stabilized? Doctor: Yeah. I think that meant that the, the CT and bone scan from August first and August second did not look any, any worse than the ones before that. They also didn’t look any better but the cancer had stopped growing and spreading further. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that what, you know, stabilizing means. So I’ve heard everything that you had to say. And it, it seems very clear that you’re leaning towards continuing on the study and I think that’s a reasonable idea. There has been nothing so far on this study that is an absolute reason to stop. An absolute reason to stop would be, for example, if your scans showed unequivocal progression of the cancer. That would be one reason. Another reason would be if your pain was getting so bad that we had to consider radiation to the bone to eliminate the pain. Uh, another would be if you had any, uh, very serious side effect to the medication that is not reversible. Uh, so, what I think we should do is this. It sounds like you want to try to give this a bit more time. I think that about two months from now, roughly, a bit less, because your scans were on August first and second, so, roughly, I think the first week of October, you’re going to be getting another CT scan and another bone scan, because this trial requires the scan every eight weeks. Uh, let’s try to keep you on the study until that point in time because that’s going to give us a lot more information about, you know, comparing that scan to the previous one and then comparing that scan to the very, very first one, your baseline, as we call it. Uh, plus by then, we’re going to have two more PSAs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To see if that’s stabilizing at all. And we’re going to know also from you how you’re feeling in terms of your bone pain. Like, is it overall getting slightly worse over time or if that’s stabilized, or is it perhaps improving? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: In order to keep you on this study, uh, from the side effect perspective, we’re going to need to temporarily stop the medication again, unfortunately- Because of this hemoglobin being eight point nine. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it’s very likely that when you come back on September fifth, your hemoglobin will be above nine, hopefully, above ten, it will recover some, in other words, uh, and then given that the hemoglobin has improved, we can put you back on the medication, but it will be at the two-hundred milligram dose. It’ll be a second level of dose reduction. Okay? Patient: Hum. Doctor: I don’t think you’ll need to go lower than that. Okay? But I think the two-fifty in terms of the anemia, uh, it did cause the same problem, again, to a lesser degree, but it did still cause the same problem. Uh, so my preference, if you want to remain on the study, which I think is reasonable, would be as of today to ask you to stop the medication until you come back and see us on September the fifth. And on that day, what we’re probably going to recommend, provided that your hemoglobin has increased again, preferably above ten, but at least above nine, is we’re going to put you back on the second dose level reduction which will be two hundred milligrams per day.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The other option again for lymph nodes of a specific size and the size limitation is more because one of the studies we have requires the smallest size of the lymph node to be one point five centimeter or higher. And that is uh a combination of a medication called Cabozantinib with an immune therapy. So that combination I think I would strongly recommend looking at if you have enough disease that needs treatment. Obviously if there’s… Patient: Are you gonna be able to find that out today? Doctor: I’m hoping to, yes. So that’s why I said let’s try and get some preliminary information on your CAT scans because that is going to be the key decision maker. Patient: More so than a bone? Doctor: I think the bone scan the problem is your report compared it to I don’t know a scan done years ago, because in between all the bone scans you had were here, they were not up there… Patient: Right. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: So I think I cannot do a whole lot by the report, I do need to look at the actual scan which I will do right now. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So I’ll tell you about both those things I’m hoping today before you leave. Patient: Before we leave.

So, let’s just backtrack for a second. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If I say gosh, where is your cancer right now, I’m not sure if I can adequately answer that by scans because the last one you had at Oakwood, hold on. Patient: Right, same thing, yeah. Doctor: Same thing, was July and then we did a quick scan to make sure nothing was happening, you know, here after the biopsy but that was just sort of kind of like limited.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: so they don’t have a way to read and say that what I’m saying correct. Because if it’s not in a document then it isn’t so. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And that’s a struggle for us, but I have a feeling that’s what it is. But hey this may be a blessing in disguise. You’ve got the fourth coming up, you might as well just enjoy it. We will reschedule next week. I’ll scream at a bunch of more people because what else do I have to do. Doctor: And then by then hopefully the shot will have worked out. Patient: Okay Doctor: If the shot doesn’t work out then we just have to stay very calm and either try a different shot which is a real pain in the neck shot because it’s an everyday shot for like three to four days that you would have to give yourself. Which if you can’t you would have to come here and we would give it to you, but that’s a cousin drug. Patient: Another chemo type. Doctor: No to get the white cells to remain up. Patient: Oh...Oh I see what you’re saying. Doctor: Yeah remember this is a shot… Family Member: So they don’t die…

text: Patient: Berries and <____>. Doctor: High fiber, low fat? Patient: Yes. As much as I can. Doctor: And you’re in good shape where you don’t have a big belly or anything like that. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So that’s good. Patient: And so the likelihood of what you’re seeing reoccurring is is is it high, minimum? Doctor: I would say, I would say based on so far minimum. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And if we go a year and find it’s still undetectable, uh then I think that uh that chances are very good that if it does reoccur that we can control it. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: I would say if it goes beyond a year I would say the risk is minimal and it continues to decrease.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
